We find that these models, which have no direct connection to the brain, can explain nearly 100% of the brain’s neural response to language. This suggests that the brain’s language processing is fundamentally computational in nature. Our results have implications for the study of language in the brain and for the future of neuroscience.

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that are constantly being assembled and disassembled. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin enhances severing of filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF/cofilin-induced twist enhances severing by 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in cells. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that are mechanosensitive. Finally, they suggest that the action of ADF/cofilin is fundamentally different from that of other ADF-related proteins.

We test whether emotional contagion occurs outside of in-person interaction between individuals by reducing the amount of emotional content in the News Feed. We find that when positive expressions were reduced, people produced fewer positive posts and more negative posts; when negative expressions were reduced, the opposite pattern occurred. These results indicate that emotions expressed by others on Facebook influence our own emotions, constituting experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are modified in a variety of ways, but the impact of these modifications on the ribosome is not well understood. Here, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in mRNA sequences can modestly alter the rate of protein synthesis and the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA sequences can have a significant impact on the ribosome, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions may be a mechanism by which the ribosome can be altered to change protein synthesis. This work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on the ribosome and the potential for these modifications to be used as a means to control protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is associated with positive change over time. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a major theme in the history of life. We use a combination of comparative analysis and the fossil record to test the extent to which the evolution of aquatic lifestyles has driven the evolution of larger body sizes. We find that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is driving the evolution of larger body sizes. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is driving the evolution of larger body sizes.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The common cold is caused by rhinovirus, a small, nonenveloped, positive-sense RNA virus. Rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. Here, we show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus induces a more efficient antiviral defense response at core body temperature than at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the common cold. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of global surface waters are unknown. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation. We show that the quality of global surface waters is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer. We also show that the virus has the potential to spread between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This is a good thing. However, the world is still dependent on fossil fuels and nuclear energy. The only way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is to use renewable energy sources. Hydropower is the leading renewable energy source. However, the world is moving away from building large dams. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, the immune system is also known to be involved in AD. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type affected in AD, produce a variety of immune factors, which are not present in glial cells. We also show that the immune response in neurons is unique, since neighboring glial cells do not express similar molecules. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, its origin and early history remain unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a major mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular response to stress is often accompanied by the generation of reactive oxygen species, which can inactivate the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme. Here, we show that, in the presence of such stress, a second enzyme, RppH, is activated and takes over the role of decapping Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme has a unique mechanism for recognizing 5′ termini, which is distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. This unconventional mechanism for recognizing capped 5′ ends could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during stress. Our findings also suggest that the rate at which capped RNAs are deprotected may be a critical determinant of the extent to which bacterial adaptability to stress is compromised. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the planet. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change is proportional to the system’s energy. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of event times. The simplest SOC system is the sandpile model, where the energy is the number of unstable sites and the rate of change is the addition of energy to an unstable site. In this paper, we study the sandpile model in the thermodynamic limit. We show that the model exhibits a phase transition from a low-activity phase to a high-activity phase. We also show that the model exhibits a scaling limit, which is a tropical model. We discuss the connection between the sandpile model and pattern formation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, by applying a strain below the threshold for phonon instability. This opens up opportunities for tailoring its electronic and optical properties. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based devices.

The role of plant-associated microbes in the health of the host plant is well established. However, the role of the plant in the health of the associated microbes is less understood. In this study, we show that a plant-derived peptide can kill plant fungal pathogens. This peptide is structurally unique and can kill plant fungal pathogens by disrupting the fungal cell wall. This work provides a new class of plant-derived compounds that can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also provides a new paradigm for the role of the plant in the health of the associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the process of fertilization is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the maintenance of sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and to the public.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for hemostasis. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We report that force application to platelets switches the A1 domain of VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is critical for the pathophysiology of VWD. The conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the force-switched state is a thermodynamically stable state. The results provide a mechanism for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF. They also provide a platform for studying the effects of force on other proteins. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microbes that has been shown to influence human health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, is poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which we call the Human Microbiome Project Virus Database (https://www.hmpdacc.org/resources/virusdb). This database is the result of a large-scale, collaborative effort to assemble and characterize human-associated viruses. We show that the human virome is highly associated with disease. This database will be a valuable resource for future research on the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously the diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties. The observations are used to investigate the ACI process. The results show that the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidney. They are also involved in a wide range of diseases. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a major regulator of the resting membrane potential of the heart. It is also involved in the regulation of blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac contractility. The BK channel is unique in that it lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Our findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of the BK channel. They also provide a theoretical framework for the study of other K+ channels. They may also lead to the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias and other diseases.

Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new antimalarial drugs. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for seasonal influenza epidemics. Our study may also be relevant to the impact of dry air on other respiratory viral infections. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this process is still lacking. Here, we show that the brain activity associated with the merge operation increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This activity is distributed across multiple regions of the language network, including the superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. The results are consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our findings provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for the rapid comprehension of spoken language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for the development of the nervous system, the skeleton, and the immune system. The pathway is regulated by the degradation of β-catenin, which is dependent on the binding of the protein Axin to the Wnt signal. We show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work may help to understand the evolution of redundant genes in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major public health problem. The mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we report a circuit that may contribute to overeating. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by dopamine receptor antagonists, suggesting that dopamine is involved. We also show that this circuit is downstream of the ventral tegmental area, a brain region that is involved in the regulation of feeding.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of both partners. However, the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in these associations is low, limiting their use in agriculture. Here, we have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture and to develop sustainable agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest. It is also one of the most threatened. The region is experiencing the highest rates of deforestation in the world, and the rate of deforestation is increasing. The Amazon is also home to indigenous peoples, who are often the most directly affected by deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to provide indigenous communities with early alerts about deforestation in their territories and to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s short duration.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the animal’s body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is not constrained by the body and can be extended to 10,000 times the size of the spider itself. The spider can also regenerate its web, which is a unique feature for sensing and repairing. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. It also provides a new model system for studying the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors.

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the combined effects of fossil-fuel-related emissions and anthropogenic aerosols on global climate are not. We show that the combined effects can be as large as the effects of greenhouse gases. This is important for the climate negotiations, because aerosols are not regulated under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Our results suggest that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. This would be a major step toward a sustainable future.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with over 500,000 deaths in the United States alone. Vaccines are needed to contain the pandemic, but the current vaccines are not affordable for low- and middle-income countries. We report a recombinant protein that can be expressed in bacteria at high yield, which can be used to manufacture a vaccine. This protein can be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine, which can be used to protect against variants of concern. This work provides a platform for the development of a vaccine that can be manufactured at low cost and can be used to contain the pandemic. This work is expected to contribute to the global fight against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. The majority of cases is sporadic, but a significant fraction is associated with a germline mutation in the gene encoding the ALK receptor tyrosine kinase. In this study, we show that the zebrafish ALK homolog Alkals can activate the zebrafish Ltk homolog Ltk. Furthermore, we show that Alkals are required for zebrafish iridophore development. Our results provide in vivo evidence for the involvement of ALK/Ltk signaling in neural crest development. This is of importance for the understanding of the pathogenesis of neuroblastoma and other neural crest-derived tumors. Our findings also suggest that ALK/Ltk signaling is a promising therapeutic target in neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of life. We present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the evolution of this pathogen. We find that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic was not diversified during this period, but rather, dispersed across Eurasia. This suggests that the plague pandemic was not the result of a single event, but rather, the result of a series of events over millennia. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Iberia, which was previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted support for Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) is a key resource for agriculture and the environment. However, the fate of SOC in agricultural systems is highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage in the top 1 m of soil. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and the addition of manure and cover crops. These results are consistent with a meta-analysis of published studies. We also show that the management practices that increase SOC storage also increase the use of soil resources, including microbial biomass and microbial C-use efficiency. These results highlight the importance of soil health management practices in agricultural systems and the need to balance the benefits of increased SOC storage with the potential trade-offs in soil resource use. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the highest risk viruses, which can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions. We also created a publicly accessible database, SpillOver, that can be used to monitor and improve our understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform research and public health interventions for the prevention and control of future viral threats.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main colors of nectar is red, which is thought to be an important visual cue for pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the red nectar of two distantly related species, which are both visited by hummingbirds. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, which is likely to be favored by pollinators. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the genetic history of the population during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 750 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic history of this population is very complex, and that the genetic ancestry of the women in the group is very heterogeneous. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that the genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid, accurate, and scalable diagnostics. However, in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, the capacity for laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics is often limited. Here, we describe the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. This study demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings and the potential for rapid public health response. Ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study highlights the potential of mNGS to detect undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human cell is constantly replicating its genome. This process is highly complex and requires the faithful duplication of DNA. The lagging strand of the DNA double helix is replicated by a single-stranded DNA-polymerizing enzyme, pol δ. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the efficient replication of the lagging strand. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is highly processive and maintains a loose association with the PCNA sliding clamp. This behavior has profound implications for the replication of the lagging strand in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules and replicated by ribozymes. In the present work, we report the design, construction, and characterization of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. This RNA polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are correlated with the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Finally, we find that neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical processes that shape the urban landscape.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients is difficult. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential metal for all organisms, but its high toxicity to eukaryotic cells has led to the development of copper-binding compounds in fungi. The role of these compounds in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes is unknown. We report the discovery of xanthocillin, a family of isocyanide compounds derived from the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus. Xanthocillins bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan cluster is involved in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the regulation of interactions with microbes. (Show more)

The origin of the abundant silica on Mars is a major question. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant step forward in understanding the origin of this mineral. Tridymite is a high-temperature, low-pressure mineral, and its detection in a sedimentary rock at high-latitude Gale crater suggests that the silica is of magmatic origin.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major cause of crop failure. The geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and this change is expected to be more pronounced in some regions than in others. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and this change is expected to be more pronounced in some regions than in others.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can induce colitis in a Stat4-dependent manner. In addition, we show that Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Further studies are needed to determine the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms of disease progression are not fully understood. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. This method can be used to study other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates pathogen colonization. We show that the ability of antifreeze glycoprotein to alter the gut microbiota is dependent on its ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be critical for the development of vector control strategies for vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we report a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without a detailed understanding of the underlying processes. In this paper, we show that one of the most important processes in the climate system is the transport of water vapor from the troposphere to the stratosphere.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to communicate with conspecifics, to avoid predation, or to blend in with the environment. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is present in many species and has been described in other animals, but its function has not been characterized.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes cancer stem cells are not well understood. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a breast cancer stem cell factor. This study provides a mechanism for how hypoxia promotes the cancer stem cell phenotype, and suggests that targeting ALKBH5 may be a strategy for cancer therapy. This study also provides a mechanism for how m6A modification regulates the cancer stem cell phenotype. Thus, m6A modification may be a target for cancer therapy.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these early pocket Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to study the production of other ancient manuscripts. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is based on five ash beds, each of which is interpreted as a depositional marker for a major extinction event. The age model defines an extinction interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility that persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values is consistent with the hypothesis that the extinction was triggered by a global environmental perturbation. The new age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, permitting insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also allow a more precise evaluation of the role of the carbon cycle in the extinction and its aftermath.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific role of RORα is not well understood. Here, we generated IEC-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for neutralizing antibodies. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in complex with the ACE2 receptor, and we have compared the structure of the spike in complex with the receptor for two common mutations in the spike protein. We find that the mutations are associated with a more open conformation of the spike protein. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. Our results provide insight into the impact of the mutations on the structure and function of the spike protein.

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These findings underscore the need for public health interventions to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and other causes of death.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other fields, such as materials science. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and we provide a quantitative description of this effect. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. This work is of fundamental importance, and it can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme fire events. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have the potential to reduce the risk of extreme fire events, and that this could offset some of the warming caused by human emissions. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowed by up to 0.11 °C by 2100, but that this effect is most likely to occur under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights the importance of human ignitions in driving fire regimes, and the need for more research on the effects of climate change on human ignitions.

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify topics in a large corpus of violent death narratives. We find that the corpus is dominated by a small number of topics, and that the corpus is gender biased. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identity of the putative reservoirs of plague in Europe has been the subject of intense debate. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Instead, we find that the introduction of plague into Europe was a recurrent event, with a delay of 15 y, which is consistent with the existence of a trans-Eurasian trade network. This trade network is likely to have been the result of the Silk Road system, which was in operation during the second plague pandemic. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not the result of a single introduction of plague, but rather of a series of introductions, each of which was followed by a delay of 15 y. This suggests that the disease was introduced into Europe by a trans-Eurasian trade network

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a major prey item for a variety of predators. In the past few years, a disease has emerged that has led to the mass mortality of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML patients is poor. The IL1RAP (IL1R3) is expressed on AML cells and is a target for antibody-based therapy. We show here that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can kill AML cells in vitro and in vivo. Furthermore, we show that the antibody can block IL-1 signaling and inhibit the proliferation of AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof-of-concept for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy of AML. The results are relevant for the development of antibody-based therapies for other diseases in which IL1RAP is expressed. The results are relevant for the development of antibody-based therapies for other diseases in which IL1RAP is expressed.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a complex history of settlement. We find that Madagascar was settled by a mixture of African and Asian populations, with a sex bias in the settlement. The settlement happened recently, within the last few centuries, and the genetic structure is already detectable. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a valuable resource for future studies.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. The COVID-19 pandemic has been prolonged by the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants. The emergence of variants with mutations that reduce or eliminate binding to antibodies has been a major obstacle to the development of effective vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding of antibodies to their targets. We demonstrate the utility of this algorithm by optimizing the binding of an antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 variants to multiple variants. We show that the optimized antibody is more potent against variants than the original antibody. Our results highlight the potential of deep learning to be used in the development of next-generation antibodies. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to overcome the current COVID-19 pandemic and future pandemics.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide the USDA with a continuous and reliable source of information on the status of crops across the country. However, the information provided by the experts is qualitative and subjective. We show how to convert this information into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We show that the resulting Crop Condition Index can be used to predict crop yields with up to 10% accuracy earlier than the official USDA forecasts. This index can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This information is critical for the agricultural sector, which is increasingly exposed to climate change and other environmental factors.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change is poorly understood. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, totaling over 3,800 observations. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. This lack of evidence for acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in major biome types suggests that soil respiration may not be a major driver of future increases in global temperatures. However, our results also demonstrate that soil respiration may be more responsive to warming in colder climates than warmer climates, which may have important implications for the global carbon cycle. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it is associated with a major change in the selection pressure on the genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the evolutionary rates of plastid genes reach several new rate equilibria during the process of functional reduction. These equilibria are linked to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. The evolutionary rates of plastid genes are expected to be a powerful tool for the study of the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. This article is protected by copyright. The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% under high-emission scenarios by the year 2100. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to avoid the most severe droughts in the region. This is particularly true for the most vulnerable populations, who are likely to be the first to suffer the consequences of climate change. This article is protected by copyright. The discovery of quasicrystals has revolutionized condensed matter physics. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The age of the sample is known precisely because it contains a chemical element that was not present in the world before the atomic bomb was developed. This discovery has important implications for the study of quasicrystals and for the study of the history of the world. It also has implications for the study of the origin of the universe.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is one of the most important and productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the synthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. Here, we show that the two classes of enzyme are related, and that they are required for oxygenic photosynthesis. We also show that a third class of enzyme exists, which is required for oxygenic photosynthesis in purple bacteria. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroprotective strategies are needed to reduce neuroinflammation. Neuroprotective effects of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase 1 (ASK1) have been reported, but the molecular mechanisms are unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages reduced neuroinflammation in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes reduced neuroinflammation only in the later stage of EAE. These findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the early stage, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a major role in the later stage of EAE. ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes may be potential therapeutic targets for reducing neuroinflammation in EAE. The 2012–2014 drought in California is the most severe in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought has increased substantially in the past two decades, and that this increase is almost entirely due to human-caused global warming.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal genes and the causal pathways. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for understanding the causal genes and causal pathways of autism. It also provides a framework for understanding the mechanisms of autism. These findings will be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for autism. (Show more)

The news media are under intense scrutiny for their role in the 2016 US presidential election. This work offers a cross-national demonstration of the extent to which the news media are dominated by negative content. It also offers a cross-national demonstration of the extent to which individual variation in news consumption is related to the extent to which people consume negative content. The results suggest that the news media are not just dominated by negative content, but that there is considerable individual-level variation in the extent to which people consume negative content. These results have implications for the news media, for the study of news consumption, and for the study of the psychology of news consumption.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare, multisystem disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that patients with Stormorken syndrome have mutations in STIM1, a protein that regulates store-operated Ca2+ entry. We show that STIM1 mutations result in constitutive activation of the store-operated Ca2+ entry pathway, and that these mutations cause bleeding diathesis and thrombocytopenia in zebrafish embryos. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome, and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with this disorder. (Show more)

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. The mechanisms that underlie this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and spread throughout the brain. We also show that aggregates cause non–cell-autonomous pathology, including loss of vulnerable neurons. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading and pathology in neurodegenerative diseases. Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may help to elucidate the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases. This knowledge may help to mitigate the risk of future viral spillover from bats. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth. One-carbon units are required for cell growth, and are provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of both human SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell malignancies. We also show that a glycine-deficiency metabolic defect is a targetable deficiency of DLBCL. Thus, this study provides a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of proteins, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS). These proteins are highly aggregation-prone and form inclusions in the brains of patients with ALS. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusions are populated by proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the inclusions in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This is a significant finding, as it suggests that the inclusions in ALS are a direct consequence of the disease process, rather than being a result of the presence of a single protein. This may have implications for the design of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that this work will inspire future experiments and inspire the design of new photonic crystal devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants has been hampered by the lack of fossils. Here, we present a detailed study of the earliest flowering plant, Montsechia vidalii. The study of this plant, which is 100 y old, has been difficult because of the poor quality of the original material. We have studied more than 1,000 specimens, which have allowed us to present a detailed description of the plant, including its reproduction. The study of this plant has important implications for the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a major topic of interest in the field of virology. In this study, we present the first ancient viral sequences of human parvovirus B19 (B19V). We show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This is well known, but the rate of rise is not. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of rise, and it is higher than previous estimates. This higher rate of rise is consistent with the rate of rise predicted by climate models.

Pain is a major public health problem, but the course of pain over the life course is not well understood. We show that pain is increasing with age in the United States, but that this increase is not seen for the elderly. Instead, pain is increasing with age for all adults, but more so for those born after 1950. This pattern is not seen for the more educated, but is seen for the less educated.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This picture is used to understand the fate of the leaving group in the reaction back to the preceding transition state, and to explain why the natural substrate indole, but not benzimidazole, reacts with the intermediate. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a critical need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and also suggests that remdesivir may be effective against other coronaviruses. This study may also be relevant for the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The development of effective antiviral treatments is critical for the control of MERS and the emerging novel coronavirus. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of these diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that this glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiosis, and that its catabolism modulates the pH of the symbiotic organ. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes, and suggests that the provision of nutrients may be a more common mechanism than previously thought. Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a scalable, evidence-based intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. The intervention is simple: teachers are trained to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention is scalable because it can be implemented by teachers themselves, with minimal training. It is also effective.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to transcriptional mutagenesis. However, the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. We found that the minor-groove alkylation of DNA can lead to transcriptional stalling, whereas the major-groove alkylation can lead to multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help us to understand the impact of alkylation on transcriptional fidelity and will provide important insights into the design of DNA alkylation-resistant drugs. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may also be relevant to other coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this system. In this study, we show that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a catering environment by 70% without a significant impact on overall sales. This is a significant contribution to the fight against climate change.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of six isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The 2020 presidential election is likely to be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2016 presidential election. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s share of the vote or their vote share. However, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. They also suggest that vote-by-mail may be a useful tool for safeguarding the electoral process in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is a novel pathogen, and the molecular mechanisms by which it causes disease are not fully understood. Here, we report the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the unique immune evasion and spread properties of SARS-CoV-2. This knowledge will be critical for the development of effective countermeasures. Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are “strong”—that is, that have a large effect size. But how do we assess the strength of an association? This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will be useful to researchers in the social and behavioral sciences.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimal set of transcription factors that induce EC development remains unknown. Here, we show that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is sufficient to induce EC development from human adult skin fibroblasts. ETV2-induced EC development is accompanied by the expression of multiple endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1. ETV2-induced EC development also results in the formation of mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Our study provides a potential strategy for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study also provides a better understanding of the mechanism of human EC development. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Recently, two ligands, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) were discovered. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We demonstrate that augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore differentiation and that they are activated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides a better understanding of the function of these orphan RTKs and their ligands in vivo. It also provides a model system for the study of the function of these ligands in other organisms. This study may lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets for cancer and other diseases.
