Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder that is associated with insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are still unclear, it is well established that STING is involved in the regulation of immune response. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we show that STING is required for normal β-cell function and is decreased in islets of T2D mice and patients. Moreover, we found that STING deficiency impairs glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These findings establish a pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of T2D. Furthermore, it may provide a potential target for the treatment of T2D. However, further studies are needed to confirm this hypothesis. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza. They cause annual epidemics and occasionally severe pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight RNA fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. We demonstrated that this interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction decreased the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of influenza A virus replication. It also provides a basis for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The atheroprone flow environment is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the mechanisms by which the flow environment regulates the development of atherosclerotic lesions remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the atheroprone flow environment is critical for the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the atheroprone flow-induced activation of YAP/TAZ and its downstream target genes, which may be a potential target for the development of athero-protective therapies. This study also provides a platform for the development of athero-protective therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfires are a natural and important part of many ecosystems. However, in the United States, human activities have greatly increased the extent of the fire niche, and have made the fire season longer and more intense. This has increased the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the geographic and seasonal extent of human-caused wildfires relative to lightning-caused wildfires. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in expanding the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that the physical appearances of neighborhoods are related to the economic and demographic characteristics of their residents. Specifically, we find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. We also find that neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Finally, we find that neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and may help to conserve biodiversity and control insect pests. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the virus in the host has been the focus of intense study. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the virus is cleared rapidly, and that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak viral load and shorten the time to undetectable viral load. These results can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral treatments for ZIKV. This work can also be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral treatments for other viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of human activities. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier between the host and the external environment. It is also a major site of immune surveillance. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the intestinal epithelium. We show that the loss of BMP signaling leads to the development of intestinal tumors. These tumors lead to the activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, which in turn leads to the dysbiosis of the microbiome. The dysbiotic microbiome leads to the activation of JNK, which in turn leads to the development of tumors. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab enhances the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. However, this attribution is based on a single proxy, and the timing of the shift is uncertain. We show that a unique volcanic eruption series, coincident with the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate response that is similar to that observed during modern ozone depletion. This provides a plausible explanation for the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation and the climate changes that followed. This work has implications for the timing of the start of the last deglaciation and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in past climate change. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries. Our data can be used to identify the locations of productive fisheries and the regions where fishing is most intense, and can be used to prioritize the conservation of biodiversity in river ecosystems. Our results highlight the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, and the need to protect them from degradation by other stressors.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate neurons is a key feature of development and a valuable property for the repair of the adult nervous system. However, the mechanisms that control the ability of neurons to regenerate are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by sensory activity and is a powerful platform for the discovery of genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Our study provides a framework for understanding the molecular control of the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. This article is protected by copyright. The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also find that recombination is more likely to terminate in exons than in introns. These results are consistent with the model that recombination initiation in eukaryotes is conserved and ancient. The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interacting networks. The present study provides a method for the identification of the main resting state networks in healthy subjects and in Parkinson’s disease. The method is based on the analysis of metabolic brain imaging, which provides a measure of total brain activity. The results show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant resting state network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. The results also show that the dominant resting state network is functionally related to cognitive function.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the best studied modification is the 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification of tRNA. In this study, we describe a 5′ NAD+ modification of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNA (mRNA) in yeast. We show that this modification is not a product of posttranscriptional processing, but is instead produced cotranscriptionally. This modification may have important functional consequences for the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNA. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of people with diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT). These DNA-me differences are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of metabolic memory and may help to identify new targets for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This study may also provide a potential target for TNBC therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also shows that the gut barrier and the microbiota are linked to psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. This may be important in the development of relapse. Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Tomato fruit are a major source of food flavor, and the quality of this flavor is highly dependent on the content of volatile compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not well understood, and the contribution of nitrogenous compounds to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of a single precursor. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also provides a model for the study of the biosynthesis of other classes of nitrogenous flavor compounds. (Show more)

Biodiversity is a key component of ecosystem functioning, but the effects of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are not well understood. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the effects of temperature change in the context of biodiversity loss, and suggest that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the impacts of global warming on the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It is thought to encode the local environment in the form of a map, but the organization of this map is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be the main MEC cell type involved in creating the map, are strongly coupled to each other, but not to other cell types. These findings provide a more complete picture of the organization of the MEC map. They also suggest that the MEC map is not a simple grid, but rather a more complex structure. This work provides a framework for future studies of the organization of the MEC map.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the Cuscuta australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts. This may optimize parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the dopamine-producing capacity of the remaining neurons. The present study describes a previously unidentified system of neurons that are critical to the functioning of the dopamine-producing neurons. The system is composed of striatonigral fibers that originate in the striatum and project to striatonigral fibers that originate in the striosomes. The striosomes are a small group of neurons in the medial wall of the striatum that are thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. We are social creatures, and we seek connection. But how do we know when we are connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust signal of connection. We show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust signal of connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN cells (SANCs) are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, and that this effect was associated with increased levels of silicon and jasmonic acid (JA) and enhanced JA-mediated defense responses. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the metabolism of other lipids, including glycosylated ceramides and cardiolipins. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. Furthermore, we show that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings may help to understand the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism and may provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies. Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food for the human population. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to deliver siRNA to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution is one of the greatest threats to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries are important sources of nutrients to large water bodies, but that they may also be important for fueling coastal algal blooms. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient pollution on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective. We find that the network exhibits a strong tendency to concentrate in a few states that are extremized with respect to the environment. We discuss the implications of this behavior for the study of complex systems in general and for the study of complex networks in particular.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis causes changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous electroencephalogram (EEG) activity. We use a dynamic model of the brain to show that these changes are explained by changes in the synaptic parameters of the brain. We then use a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis to show that these changes are sufficient to cause paroxysms of EEG activity. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms of autoimmune encephalitis. They also suggest that the same mechanisms may be at play in other forms of autoimmune encephalitis. This may have implications for the treatment of these conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid transition from a greenhouse to an icehouse state. This transition is expected to be accompanied by abrupt climate changes. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was accompanied by a global warming and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and to an increase in nutrient fluxes. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of abrupt climate change and the potential for future abrupt climate change. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that the RSPO is not yet achieving its stated goals.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. It is essential to organisms across kingdoms. However, the molecular mechanism of its regulation is not well understood. Here, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. This study also provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in the evolution of animals. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to produce a range of sex classes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple interacting sex determination alleles can provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of multiple interacting sex determination alleles can lead to the evolution of higher-order sexual polymorphism. This can be important for understanding the evolution of sex-biased traits and the maintenance of sexual dimorphism.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by reactive oxygen species. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in the retina, promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the intracellular levels of iron may be a target for the treatment of this blinding disease. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of iron in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. Predator specialization is a fundamental process in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the evolution of modularity in the organism. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the paucity of fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand. This feature is the third metacarpal styloid process, which is present in the modern human hand but not in any other hominin. The study of this fossil and its implications for the evolution of the human hand are discussed. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth. One-carbon units are required for cell growth, and are provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of both human SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell malignancies. We also show that a glycine-deficiency metabolic defect is a targetable deficiency of DLBCL. Thus, this study provides a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. The world is facing a food crisis, and the agricultural sector is the main focus of efforts to increase food production. However, little attention is paid to the role of natural landscapes such as forests in meeting nutrition goals. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamins. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is a positive development. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in meeting both food and nutrition goals. This study also has implications for researchers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. Finally, the study has implications for practitioners, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. This study provides a causal link between deforestation and people’s dietary quality, and the results have important implications for policy makers, researchers, practitioners, and the general public.

Modern agriculture is the most productive and efficient food production system in history. However, it has come at a cost of soil degradation, with the risk of subsoil compaction becoming a major concern. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over the course of modern mechanization, with the risk of compaction now exceeding the safe mechanical limits for soil functioning. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis needs to be tested in the field. (Show more)
